children.subject: Nvm, it is.
Does MATH 53 also count if I took it as transfer course from community college?
Students are never forced to graduate early. You can choose which classes you take for the UD Tech Electives, Math 53 is simply an option.
Can I choose not to waive the upper division tech elective so that I don't graduate early?
See original post; we're not advising here.
Will multivariable calculus courses articulated on assist.org but taken while enrolled in high school count?
+1 I took the math 53 equivalent in Cal State Fullerton and it appears in my transfer report as well.

OP: "Math 53 courses fully articulated on assist.org will also count." 

Student commenter: the Math department would need to review your CSU course and confirm it is equivilant.

Just to clarify: I took Multivariable at a community college during high school, and it appears as an articulated course on assist.org (and is in my Transfer Credits Report on CalCentral). Does this mean it applies towards the 4 unit upper div tech elective as detailed in this post?
It does I believe
Will Math W53 count?
No. The EECS Major has completely different requirements and already requires math 53.
what about for 161? will that count as design req for EECS?
Ahhh! Good question! Totally forgot about that part. I'll ask tomorrow and update ASAP
Yes, see my email to be sent in 5 minutes.
Is this for EECS majors as well
See original post; we're not advising here.
Does the Math 53 clause also apply to transfer credit from institutions outside of CA? I've already received credit for it on my transfer report, so can I apply this towards the major requirements?
I went to drop advising. Math 53 does not count overlap
So we can overlap two courses AND make math53 one of our upper electives? Wowww
Yes.

As a Math / CS double major, will Math 53 count towards the two-class max overlap between Math and CS? Since it’s a lower division course I’m assuming no, but would appreciate confirmation! (Apologies if this is a question better answered in advising)
See original post; we're not advising here.
I am a Math & CS double major. If I use Math 53 as a CS tech elective, will it count an overlapping course?
Yes
I'm just a CS major - will Math 53 satisfy 4 units of upper-division tech elective coursework for the CS major?
Take Math 54
Any way to waive EE16A?
I'm pretty sure the course curriculum has remained constant throughout the years, so I am also very curious as to why this can't be applied to past semesters' offerings (I took 161 in Fall 2018).
See original post; we're not advising here.

1. As of Spring 2019, CS161 will count as a design class. Previous offerings of this class will not count toward this requirement, however starting Spring 2019 and going forward, CS161 will count toward the 4-unit design requirement.

Is this due to a change in the course curriculum, or just that it's not retroactively possible to count previous semesters as a design requirement?
It would not make any sense to count a regular version but reject a honors version, so I would think yes.
See original post; we're not advising here.
Will math H53 also count?
See original post; we're not advising here.
Will CS 161 count as a design course for EECS majors as well? There seems to be nearly full crossover in terms of design course listings between CS and EECS otherwise.
See original post; we're not advising here.
If I need Math 53 for my data science domain emphasis will this count as a course overlap for CS/DS double major?
Woo hoo! Thank you!

PSA:  Math W53 (web-based version with in-person final exam) for Summer 2019 still has space.   http://summer.berkeley.edu/courses/online/math-w53

So do several sections of N53.
See original post; we're not advising here.
Might be dumb. If I failed Math53, retook and passed it with letter grade, can Math53 be counted as upper div electives?
The exception request form is not available anymore
According to the FAQ, the deadline for major application form is Dec 30 so I would assume the same for the exception request form. But to be sure, this is best for a staff to confirm.
Exception requests are accepted and reviewed on an ongoing basis, so there's no deadline.
When is the deadline for the exception request form?
<md>I discovered that the fact that COMPSCI 161 satisfies design requirement is not reflected in our APR. I wonder if it will be updated accordingly.</md>

history.content:
Dear Students,

We have two updates to the CS curriculum that are effective immediately:
  1. As of Spring 2019, CS161 will count as a design class. Previous offerings of this class will not count toward this requirement, however starting Spring 2019 and going forward, CS161 will count toward the 4-unit design requirement.
  2. If students take Math 53 for a letter grade and pass, you may waive 3 units of the upper-division tech elective requirement. This means you will only need to take at least 4 units of upper-division tech electives for a letter grade for the CS major. Your upper-division units for CS must total at least 24, which is why this waives 3 units, but not 4. We will update the website soon with this information, but this is effective immediately. Math 53 does not necessarily need to be taken in Spring 2019 for this to count for the major; it could be taken in a previous semester or going forward as well. Math 53 courses fully articulated on assist.org will also count. Multivariable calculus classes taken in high school will not count.
    • *Update* To apply Math 53 towards waiving 3-units of CS upper-division technical electives, it is required to submit an exceptions request form for approval.
    • Math & CS double major students should meet with a CS advisor if they have questions about this. Make an appointment in CalCentral or come to drop-in hours on Wed 10-12PM & 1-4PM in 349 Soda. 
Important announcement for getting classes evaluated for the CS major, especially IND ENG 185, Challenge Labs:
  • Classes that are submitted for the CS major MUST have a full syllabus to be evaluated. If a full syllabus is not available, it will not be evaluated.
  • This has been an issue in particular for IND ENG 185, Challenge Lab sections. Students should contact the professor and ask for a full syllabus. Otherwise, do not submit for evaluation. Sending individual projects is not sufficient.
Let us know if you have any questions.
CS Advising Team
Update: Students should make appointments/come to drop-in/email cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu with questions. We will not be responding here per @6809.
